news_header: The case of Runar Gåsström highlights Cold War atomic espionage in Finland.
news_text: Runar Gåsström, a Soviet physicist, arrived in Finland in 1946 and quickly integrated into Finnish society, obtaining citizenship in 1948. He was part of a significant Soviet espionage operation aimed at gathering information on nuclear technology. Gåsström worked at the University of Helsinki's physics department, where he contributed to important scientific projects while likely acting as a spy. His background and connections raised suspicions among some in the academic community, but the political climate of post-war Finland allowed him to operate with relative impunity until his sudden departure from the country in 1954.
